body:
@pedbrgs ah interesting. How many classes do you have?

We implemented code recently (1-2 months ago) to adapt hyp cls to custom dataset class counts, which made a huge improvement, as hyp cls had been tuned to 80-class coco. You should check to make sure you have this line in your repo, or it may be out of date.
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/9f04e175f62dca079f2e6c829f97dbb32e66b33d/train.py#L84
Noise in val sets is usually due to statistics, simply less images than your train set.
BTW, 30 epochs is far too little. You should start with all default settings, i.e. 300, and only update once you've seen those results.

Only two classes! So, my `hyp['cls']` will be 37.4*2/80 = 0.935?

What did you mean by "simply less images than your train set"? My training set has 32576 images and my validation set has 1208.

By the way, I will update the repository and train again. I'll put the results here as soon as I have them. Thank you!

1208 < 32576 
test set < train set 
less images = more noise

Yes, if you have not already you should definitely `git pull` to update your repository.

@glenn-jocher I train on my custom dataset which has 4 classes. So the `hyp['cls']` will be 37.4*4/80. But when I evolve the hyp for 10 loops and 30 epochs for each loop, I get a strange result just like:
`python train.py --weights 'weights/yolov3-spp-ultralytics.pt' --img-size 320 640 --epochs 30 --batch-size 16 -- accumulate 4 --evolve`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42533211/81647392-860ca100-945f-11ea-8fb0-5201f4b1ad46.png)
I have some questions:
1. Why the `hyp['cls']` can be so small compared to the original 37.4?
2. The plot of `hyp['cls']` seems different from the others. The value of `hyp['cls']` jumps from 0.121 to 1.87 suddenly, while the others are increasing smoothly.
3. Why the best result can be up to 0.9 while the others are only less than 0.5?
4. After 10 loops of evolution, only the `hyp['cls']` have been changed while the others are all the same as the original value, is that normal?

Thank you very much for your help!

@ChrisLiiiii yes this is an odd result. One of your runs was much better than the rest for some reason. Ah, I think I see what's happened. As hyp['cls'] updates each round it's gotten progressively smaller. This will require an update to the code to corrrect. The origin of the problem is a code that scales hyp cls, which we implemented recently and have not evolved since. This line modifies the value inplace by scaling it with cls count.

https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/894a3e54ca002f2296a91de3d07685f8b121b113/train.py#L84
@glenn-jocher Thanks for your reply! I'll try it later and see the evolution results.
@pedbrgs there's no such thing as mAP on the training set, it is never computed. The above plots are for coco64 dataset from the tutorial. Follow the tutorial to reproduce.
@glenn-jocher Oh, right! So, the gap is not a good measure for overfitting? As long as the val Classification / Objectness / GIoU curves don't increase, is everything okay?

@pedbrgs coco64 and coco are two different datasets, there is no comparison to be made between them.

You should train until you see overfitting, then you stop. If you don't see overfitting you haven't trained long enough.
